messages.message: Hello! What are your thoughts in Scandinavia?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Hello! What are your thoughts in Scandinavia?'.

messages.message: I would like Sweden.  In exchange, I would offer up that fleet as a proxy unit for you.  Want some help into Skag?  You got it.  Want me to help you into North Sea after I take Norway?  It's all yours.  Thoughts?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I would like Sweden.  In exchange, I would offer up that fleet as a proxy unit for you.  Want some help into Skag?  You got it.  Want me to help you into North Sea after I take Norway?  It's all yours.  Thoughts?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. Despite the offers of assistance, the request for Sweden in exchange could indicate a potential betrayal of your interests in Scandinavia.

messages.message: Hello! So it sounds like you are already planning on taking Sweden and Norway. I will confess that a strong Northern power makes me uncomfortable. If you are planning on taking Norway, you are probably committing your army in Moscow to St Pete this year then? That makes you awfully vulnerable in the south.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Hello! So it sounds like you are already planning on taking Sweden and Norway. I will confess that a strong Northern power makes me uncomfortable. If you are planning on taking Norway, you are probably committing your army in Moscow to St Pete this year then? That makes you awfully vulnerable in the south.'.

messages.message: I thought we might work together?  If I took Norway with your help, we could DMZ Scandinavia - which would allow me to focus on the South.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I thought we might work together?  If I took Norway with your help, we could DMZ Scandinavia - which would allow me to focus on the South.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. The suggestion to work together in taking Norway with the promise of DMZing Scandinavia may be a veiled attempt to secure Norway while diverting your attention and resources from other fronts.

messages.message: Anyway, that's getting way ahead of ourselves - I can't fight on two fronts, I'd rather work with you in the North and focus on the South.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Anyway, that's getting way ahead of ourselves - I can't fight on two fronts, I'd rather work with you in the North and focus on the South.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. The consistent emphasis on wanting to collaborate in the North and focus on the South suggests a genuine intention to work together and prioritize your mutual interests.

messages.message: I'd consider that if you didn't build at all in St Pete. Let me talk to France and get back to you, since I would clearly benefit more from this in an EF alliance than an EG alliance, and France has yet to say anything.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'I'd consider that if you didn't build at all in St Pete. Let me talk to France and get back to you, since I would clearly benefit more from this in an EF alliance than an EG alliance, and France has yet to say anything.'.

messages.message: Honestly, I think that I'm going to have to dedicate most of my units towards the South.  Let me know if the proxy fleet concept works for you.  I'd prefer to free up your units to do something more productive than to fight over a build in Scandinavia.

messages.message: I just dont know how useful that promise is to me unless A) I can trust you fully B) I'm all in on an English attack. I'm not saying I dont want to be friends with you, I'm just letting you know that the deal seems a bit flat.

messages.message: So ... you just auto-bounce the Russian in Sweden unless you Sealion?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'So ... you just auto-bounce the Russian in Sweden unless you Sealion?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. The question about auto-bouncing in Sweden implies doubt about your intentions and may indicate a lack of trust in your proposed actions, which could lead to potential conflict in Scandinavia.

messages.message: Look, your tone has me very concerned - you don't seem particularly interested in working with me or exploring the possibilities of us having peace between our units in Scandinavia.  I've been offering you partnership and opportunity from the get-go and not really feeling like there's any reciprocity.  Have you already made up your mind how you want to play your position and I'm wasting my time?  Or are you open to negotiation and finding common ground and working out a way we can cooperate?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Look, your tone has me very concerned - you don't seem particularly interested in working with me or exploring the possibilities of us having peace between our units in Scandinavia.  I've been offering you partnership and opportunity from the get-go and not really feeling like there's any reciprocity.  Have you already made up your mind how you want to play your position and I'm wasting my time?  Or are you open to negotiation and finding common ground and working out a way we can cooperate?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. The accusatory tone and suggestion that you are not interested in cooperation despite your attempts to negotiate and express your concerns raise doubts about their true intentions and commitment to a peaceful resolution.

messages.message: Well. You offered to support England against me, so I'm not in a very trusting mood with you. I've also heard stuff from Austria about you that is concerning, so it's not just England pulling a fast one on me. I've said I'm not opposed to working with you - and I'm certainly not opposed to keeping peace between the three of us in Scandinavia. I just cant commit in spring 01 to fight against England when France has sent very little press (and alarming press at that) and the things I am hearing about you are conflicting. Your impatience troubles me even more. Do you always nail down all of your alliances within hours of the game start?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Well. You offered to support England against me, so I'm not in a very trusting mood with you. I've also heard stuff from Austria about you that is concerning, so it's not just England pulling a fast one on me. I've said I'm not opposed to working with you - and I'm certainly not opposed to keeping peace between the three of us in Scandinavia. I just cant commit in spring 01 to fight against England when France has sent very little press (and alarming press at that) and the things I am hearing about you are conflicting. Your impatience troubles me even more. Do you always nail down all of your alliances within hours of the game start?'.

messages.message: No, but I like to feel other players out to see what they're open to and considering.  I told England that I'd be open to moving on you (Germany), which is true.  I mean, if he had said "yes, let's do it!  You can have Norway, let's lure him into bouncing you in Sweden, but in reality I'll move there while you move to Baltic and make him guess which home center to cover after you move to Silesia from Warsaw in '01 .... " I mean, yeah, I'd probably work with him.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'No, but I like to feel other players out to see what they're open to and considering.  I told England that I'd be open to moving on you (Germany), which is true. " I mean, yeah, I'd probably work with him.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. The detailed hypothetical scenario shared about potentially collaborating with England against you demonstrates a willingness to betray your trust and work against your interests, undermining the possibility of a genuine partnership.

messages.message: But just because I said that I'd be open to it, doesn't mean I was trying to get him to attack you from the jump.  I also told him what I've told you, which is that I think I need to head south and I'd just like some sort of peaceful arrangement in the north.

While they claim to seek a peaceful arrangement in the North, the earlier discussions and willingness to entertain working against you with England suggest a potential lack of sincerity in their intentions, raising doubts about their commitment to maintaining peace in the region.

messages.message: So you just admitted that you are still open to working against me rather than with me. So why are you mad at me for telling you from the start that I too am keeping my options open? Just be patient. Let me talk to France.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'So you just admitted that you are still open to working against me rather than with me. So why are you mad at me for telling you from the start that I too am keeping my options open? Just be patient. Let me talk to France.'.

messages.message: If you're getting other press from these guys that say that I'm talking about opening against Germany from the jump, and you believe it, then I think we've got some stiff competition for the $10 bounty for "best liar."  My preferred option with Germany is to leave GAL a DMZ, hold with A Moscow, and then use it against whoever lies to me in '01 (covering Warsaw from an Austrian or German in GAL/SIL, going to Norway in England lies to me, or covering SEV if Turkey opens to Armenia).  Maybe you find me too direct, but I thought we were having a conversation and then you got weird.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'If you're getting other press from these guys that say that I'm talking about opening against Germany from the jump, and you believe it, then I think we've got some stiff competition for the $10 bounty for "best liar."  My preferred option with Germany is to leave GAL a DMZ, hold with A Moscow, and then use it against whoever lies to me in '01 (covering Warsaw from an Austrian or German in GAL/SIL, going to Norway in England lies to me, or covering SEV if Turkey opens to Armenia).  Maybe you find me too direct, but I thought we were having a conversation and then you got weird.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from RUSSIA. Despite their claims of a peaceful approach and direct communication, the shifting positions and references to potential counteractions based on others lying suggest a level of deceit and strategic flexibility that may not align with genuine cooperation and trust in the game.

messages.message: I'm not mad at you, I was just reading the tone of your press.  🙂  And i read it correctly, you were worried about me trying to play you based on what you were getting from England and Austria.  I also like to keep my options open and to feel out the other players.  I don't expect other players to turn around and share my press with my opponents, because that strikes me as a poor way to demonstrate one's ability to keep quiet about things.  But thank you for letting me know that England can't be trusted.  That's valuable information.  For what it's worth, Italy is someone you probably shouldn't trust to keep your communications with him quiet, either.

messages.message: Well I'm glad that we were able to lay that out in the open. messages.message: To give you my perspective, when I play Germany, I don’t bounce Sweden in ‘01 as a general rule. I wait and see if England is working with me - if he is, taking out the solo fleet is too easy and slows down English gains. If he isn’t, then now I have a potential ally in place to help.  And if England and Russia are going to team up on me, I’m screwed anyway - but at least I haven’t provided Russia with additional motivation.   Now, WAR-SIL changes that math.

messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their observation about not being present in any of your centers reflects a straightforward assessment of the current board situation and suggests that direct assistance might be logistically challenging at the moment.

messages.message: But you supported England into my SC after I supported you
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'But you supported England into my SC after I supported you'.

messages.message: what do you want?  would you prefer to focus on england?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'what do you want?  would you prefer to focus on england?'.
messages.output: You should cautiously interpret the message from RUSSIA. The direct question about focusing on England and the implied suggestion of potentially shifting priorities could indicate a willingness to realign strategies based on your response. It's essential to consider the potential implications of this offer and how it aligns with your overall objectives in the game.

messages.message: I thought I made myself clear that England was my whole focus last phase. Now that you've allied with England against me, I have two people to be mad at now. You attacking me is more understandable than England though
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'I thought I made myself clear that England was my whole focus last phase. Now that you've allied with England against me, I have two people to be mad at now. You attacking me is more understandable than England though'.

messages.message: Oh... except you are in Bohemia and Silesia
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Oh... except you are in Bohemia and Silesia'.

messages.message: well, he agreed to dmz the north, as i explained, and then he made the moves to support it.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'well, he agreed to dmz the north, as i explained, and then he made the moves to support it.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their explanation of England agreeing to demilitarize the north and the subsequent supportive moves align with their strategic decisions and provide context for the evolving dynamics on the board, shedding light on the reasons behind their actions in collaboration with England.

messages.message: I am.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I am.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. The short statement "I am." indicates a confirmation of their current focus or position in the game, showcasing a direct and concise response that does not contain any misleading or deceptive information.

messages.message: Look, it doesn't do me great good to knock you out of the game right away.  I was wondering if you'd be open to a dialogue or are you closed off to any kind of dicussions.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Look, it doesn't do me great good to knock you out of the game right away.  I was wondering if you'd be open to a dialogue or are you closed off to any kind of dicussions.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their candid acknowledgment of the potential consequences and their approach of seeking dialogue reflect a genuine interest in exploring the possibility of diplomatic discussions and collaboration, rather than immediately resorting to aggressive actions.

messages.message: I mean I'm open to discussion, but I'm using most of my efforts with other countries since I feel like I wont be able to get very far this phase with you. In later phases things will change though
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'I mean I'm open to discussion, but I'm using most of my efforts with other countries since I feel like I wont be able to get very far this phase with you. In later phases things will change though'.

messages.message: My only real bargaining chip is helping you against England in Scandinavia, or supporting you against Austria
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'My only real bargaining chip is helping you against England in Scandinavia, or supporting you against Austria'.

messages.message: How would you suggest going about helping me against Austria?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'How would you suggest going about helping me against Austria?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their inquiry about how you propose to help them against Austria indicates a genuine interest in exploring potential collaborative strategies and highlights a willingness to engage in dialogue and coordination to address shared interests on the board.

messages.message: Well... tbh I am mostly going to be holding this phase. I'm going to Munich though, and if you relieve pressure on me I can continue south and support you there.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Well... tbh I am mostly going to be holding this phase. I'm going to Munich though, and if you relieve pressure on me I can continue south and support you there.'.

messages.message: I wouldn't mind you disbanding one of your 5 northern troops. Tbh, I dont know why you only have 2 troops protecting your south when Austria and Turkey can both attack you strongly now.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'I wouldn't mind you disbanding one of your 5 northern troops. Tbh, I dont know why you only have 2 troops protecting your south when Austria and Turkey can both attack you strongly now.'.

messages.message: Thought England was interested in working with me against you.  I have no idea why he went for Sweden instead of taking a (guaranteed) support into Kiel.  Sorry.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Thought England was interested in working with me against you.  I have no idea why he went for Sweden instead of taking a (guaranteed) support into Kiel.  Sorry.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their surprise at England's actions and the apology for the unexpected move indicate a level of confusion and potential frustration over England's decision, emphasizing the shifting dynamics and their willingness to acknowledge and address unexpected developments in the game.

messages.message: You're apologizing to me for England not attacking me?
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'You're apologizing to me for England not attacking me?'.

messages.message: Sure
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Sure'.
messages.output: You should cautiously interpret the message from RUSSIA. The response "Sure" without further explanation or clarification could indicate a nonchalant attitude or a lack of elaboration on the previous statement, suggesting that the apology might not have been conveyed as intended or that there could be a misunderstanding in the communication.

messages.message: I’m apologizing for trusting him.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I’m apologizing for trusting him.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their clarification about apologizing for trusting England reveals a sense of regret or disappointment in their previous trust in England, highlighting a candid reflection on the shifting dynamics and potential diplomatic miscalculations in the game.

messages.message: Would you like support into Denmark?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Would you like support into Denmark?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their offer of support into Denmark indicates a willingness to assist you in securing the territory, which could be beneficial for your position and align with the shared goal of countering potential threats in the region.

messages.message: If I order Kiel to Denmark you could take Berlin by force. Once you've backed off my border I'll consider moving my troops in a way other than protecting myself against invaders.
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'If I order Kiel to Denmark you could take Berlin by force. Once you've backed off my border I'll consider moving my troops in a way other than protecting myself against invaders.'.

messages.message: That’s totally fair. I’ll make that a possibility.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'That’s totally fair. I’ll make that a possibility.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their acceptance of your conditions and assurance to consider the potential for a move out of your border area once you feel more secure reflects a cooperative approach and a willingness to accommodate your strategic needs in the game.

messages.message: what do you want me to build?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'what do you want me to build?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their direct question about what to build for the upcoming phase demonstrates a willingness to collaborate and align their unit build decisions with your strategic needs and mutual objectives, indicating a cooperative approach to decision-making in the game.

messages.message: An army would be preferable
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'An army would be preferable'.

messages.message: done.  can we go our separate ways?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'done.  can we go our separate ways?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their straightforward question about parting ways indicates a clear and honest communication regarding their intentions and openness to potentially diverging paths in the game, showing a respectful approach to diplomatic interactions.

messages.message: Yeah, I'm trying to figure out what Austria and Italy are doing now
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Yeah, I'm trying to figure out what Austria and Italy are doing now'.

messages.message: well, Italy is about to get desparate for dots.  So, I'd watch your back.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'well, Italy is about to get desparate for dots.  So, I'd watch your back.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their warning about Italy's potential desperation for supply centers and the advice to watch your back highlight a strategic insight and a consideration of the evolving power dynamics on the board, indicating a shared interest in preserving your position amidst changing circumstances.

messages.message: I build the army and would like to head south.  I'd appreciate it if you held off from attacking STP or headed towards Warsaw.  i honestly believe that you have bigger fish to fry and can makes some great headway with your fleets if you head west.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'I build the army and would like to head south.  I'd appreciate it if you held off from attacking STP or headed towards Warsaw.  i honestly believe that you have bigger fish to fry and can makes some great headway with your fleets if you head west.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their request for you to refrain from attacking St. Petersburg or heading towards Warsaw, as well as the encouragement for you to focus on advancing with your fleets towards the west, suggests a collaborative approach and an alignment of interests in the distribution of forces to maximize gains for both of you.

messages.message: Why are you sending your fleet at me?
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'Why are you sending your fleet at me?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their question about your fleet's movement towards them indicates a genuine inquiry into your strategic intentions and a desire to understand the reasoning behind your actions, reflecting an open and direct approach to communication in the game.

messages.message: Please, if I wanted to attack you I'd go from Norway. Baltic was going to cover Berlin, but now it will bounce in Denmark
messages.input: My response to RUSSIA:'Please, if I wanted to attack you I'd go from Norway. Baltic was going to cover Berlin, but now it will bounce in Denmark'.

messages.message: classical mid-game mistake, going after Russia instead of Austria.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'classical mid-game mistake, going after Russia instead of Austria.'.
messages.output: You should cautiously interpret the message from RUSSIA. Their observation about the potential strategic error of focusing on Russia instead of Austria may indicate a strategic insight or a subtle attempt to redirect your attention towards Austria. It would be wise to consider this feedback within the context of your overall diplomatic and strategic goals in the game.

messages.message: the problem with weakening Russia at this point - is by the time you shift towards Austria, there's no  way to beat him off - and you can't hold Warsaw and Moscow against him.
messages.input: Message from RUSSIA:'the problem with weakening Russia at this point - is by the time you shift towards Austria, there's no  way to beat him off - and you can't hold Warsaw and Moscow against him.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from RUSSIA. Their analysis of the risks of weakening Russia too early in the game, considering the power dynamics and the challenges in shifting focus towards Austria later, demonstrates a strategic understanding of the potential consequences and the need for careful decision-making to navigate complex diplomatic situations in the game.

messages.message: He only has 4 SCs

messages.message: France?

The response "Eye roll" may convey a sense of skepticism or disagreement with the suggestion that France would be the primary beneficiary of Italy's supply centers, hinting at a different perspective or potential dynamics at play in the game that might challenge conventional assumptions.

messages.message: Those two have been cuddle buddies from the jump
